title: Characterization and Analysis of Additively Manufactured Maraging Steel by Analytical Electron Microscopy with Electron Energy Loss Spectroscopy, X-ray Energy Dispersive Spectroscopy, and 4D-STEM
content: Additive manufacturing (AM) to produce complex structural engineering components, with comparable material properties to bulk alloys produced by conventional manufacturing methods, has grown immensely over the past 10 years, creating demand from multiple industrial and defense sectors, including aerospace, naval, nuclear and military applications. With the introduction of improved and more robust 3D printing technology, as well as more accessible powder stock for printing, laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) has emerged as a viable candidate to AM ultra-high strength structural alloys, specifically maraging 300 steels.
